qas.question: What was a rule for disabled people in the past for education?
Who denied children with disabilities to be unable to attend a public school?
Who were some of these early physicians?
What would Special Education usually only apply to in the early years of schooling in the U.S?
What was a rule for non-disabled people in the past for education?
Who didn't deny children with disabilities to be unable to attend a public school?
Who were some of these modern physicians?
Who does modern special education exclude?

context: In the past, those who were disabled were often <a0_0><b4_0>not eligible for public education<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Children with disabilities were repeatedly denied an education by <a1_0><b5_0>physicians or special tutors<b5_0/><a1_0/>. These early physicians (people like <a2_0><b6_0>Itard, Seguin, Howe, Gallaudet<b6_0/><a2_0/>) set the foundation for special education today. They focused on individualized instruction and functional skills. In its early years, special education was only provided to <a3_0><b7_0>people with severe disabilities<b7_0/><a3_0/>, but more recently it has been opened to anyone who has experienced difficulty learning.
